Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Splinting and Steroid Injection for Trigger Finger

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised into three groups: splinting (n = 43), steroid injection (n = 40), and combination therapy (n = 37)

Participants.evidence: 120 adult patients with trigger finger were randomised; Eligibility criteria included adults without prior corticosteroid injection or concomitant hand conditions

Intervention.evidence: splinting involved wearing a fixed metacarpophalangeal joint orthosis; Steroid injection consisted of 1 mL of 1% lidocaine and 1 mL of triamcinolone acetonide

Objective.evidence: evaluated the effectiveness of splinting alone, steroid injection alone, and their combination in reducing pain and improving function

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were VAS pain reduction and MHQ score improvement at 6, 12, and 52 weeks

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using computer-generated block randomisation with allocation concealment via sequentially numbered, opaque, sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Both the allocator and outcome assessor were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: 120 adult patients with trigger finger were randomised into three groups: splinting (n = 43), steroid injection (n = 40), and combination therapy (n = 37)

Number_Analysed.evidence: in both intention-to-treat and per-protocol analyses

Result_Outcome.evidence: No clinically important differences in VAS pain scores or MHQ scores were observed among the groups at any timepoint
